seriesJson.title: Gateway to ideas
seriesJson.description: This discussion series, produced by the American Library Association, features noted authors, critics and scholars on various topics.

node.title: #8: Should We Be Educating For Excellence
#18 "Africa: Past, Present, and Future" with Quincy Howe
#3: Wanted: A Redefinition of the Classics
#19 "The US and the Western Alliance" with Quincy Howe
#14: The U.S. and the Far East
Education and social change
node.description: This program focuses on the links between education and social change. The moderator is Dr. Harold Taylor. Guests are Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist; and Dr. Melvin Tumin, Princeton University.

node.title: Shifting role of the university
node.description: This program explores the role of the university in modern American society. The moderator is Dr. Harold Taylor. Guests are: Dr. Charles Frankel; and Professor Daniel Bell, both of Columbia University.

node.title: Is science sterilizing humanistic thought?
node.description: This program asks the question of the extent to which science has changed the way humanity thinks. The guest is I.I. Robbie, Columbia University.

node.title: Will man be modified?
node.description: This program explores how humans will evolve in the ever-changing environment. The discussion is moderated by L.U. Bell, science editor, New York Herald Tribune. Guests are Dr. Ruth Sager, Columbia University; and Amran Scheinfeld, author, "Your Heredity and Environment."

node.title: Protestant ethic today
node.description: This program discusses the Protestant ethic in the twentieth century. The moderator is Dr. Benjamin Nelson of SUNY Stony Brook. Panelists are Professor James M. Gustafson, Yale University; and Professor Thomas F. O'Day, Columbia University.

node.title: Present-day immigration waves
node.description: Present-Day Immigration Waves. Moderator: Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine. Pietro DeDonato, novelist; Dr. Seymour Yelland, New York U.

node.title: The job of the presidency
node.description: The Job of the Presidency. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. Dr. Louis Koenig, New York U., author, "The Chief Executive," and Dr. Charles Masterson, exec dir National Safety Council

node.title: The U.S. and Western alliance
node.description: The U.S. and the Western Alliance. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. Prof. Richard Lowenthal, Free U. of Berlin and author, "World Communism"; Prof. William T.R. Fox, Columbia U.

node.title: Africa: Past, present and future
node.description: Africa: Past, Present and Future. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. George Loft, sr vice president, African American Institute; George Houser, a founder of Congress of Racial Equality (CORE)

node.title: Spiritual poverty
node.description: Spiritual Poverty. Moderator: Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine. Bill Hubbard, 17 year old Columbia U. student who produced play based on "A Man of All Work," and Rev. William S. Van Meter

node.title: Books into mass media
node.description: Books Into Mass Media. Moderator: Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine. Horace Alpert, film critic, Saturday Review.

node.title: Can attitudes be legislated?
node.description: Can Attitudes be Legislated? Leo Rosten, senior editor, Look magazine, moderates. Dr. Howard Zinn, Boston U., author of "The Southern Mystique"

node.title: The U.S. and the Far East
node.description: The U.S. and the Far East. Moderator: Quincy Howe, editor, Atlas magazine. O. Edmond Club, Columbia U., author of "Twentieth Century China"

node.title: The changing role of magazines
node.description: The Changing Role of Magazines. Moderator: Leonard Robinson, Columbia U. Geraldine Rhodes, exec. editor, McCall's; Ralph Backland, managing editor, Horizon magazine

node.title: Are the arts becoming incomprehensible
node.description: Are the Arts Becoming Incomprehensible? Moderator: Anne Fremantle. Harold Rosenberg, critic, author of "The Anxious Object"; Claude Marks (or Marx), author.

node.title: What makes a good biography
node.description: what Makes a Good Biography? Moderator: Anne Fremantle. Leon Edel, Pulitzer Prize winning author; Prof. James Gifford, Columbia U.

node.title: Let's redefine tolerance
node.description: Let's Redefine Tolerance. Features Daniel Patrick Moynihan, co-author of Beyond the Melting Pot. Moderator: Anne Fremantle.

node.title: Each to the other
node.description: Each to the Other. A discussion of the cross-fertilization of French and American literature. Maria Jolas, Ira Morris. Moderator: Anne Fremantle.

node.title: Should we educate for excellence?
node.description: Should We Educate for Excellence? Dr. Abraham Tannenbaum, Yeshiva U.; Dr. Harold Whiteman, New York U. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.

node.title: Changing attitudes toward women
node.description: Changing Attitudes Toward Women. Margaret Cousins, Doubleday and Co.; Morton Hunt, author. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.

node.title: Who sets standards and values?
node.description: Who Sets Standards and Values? Harding Lemay, publishing executive; Dr. Terence Hopkins, Columbia U. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.

node.title: Freud and twentieth century literature
node.description: Freud and 20th Century Literature. Dr. Benjamin Nelson, SUNY Stony Brook and editor of Freud and the 20th Century; Dr. Philip Weissman of New York Psychoanalytic Society. Moderator: Virginia Peterson.

node.title: Wanted: Redefinition of classics
node.description: This program presents a discussion on redefining the classics. Panelists are Elizabeth Hardwick, co-founder of New York Review of Books; and Steven Marcus, Columbia University.

node.title: Books that formed my opinions
node.description: Books that Formed my Opinions. Rep. John Lindsay of New York; Leon Edel, Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award Winner for his biography of Henry James.

node.title: Labor, leisure and automation
node.description: Labor Leisure and Automation. Leo Perlis of AFL-CIO; Edward T. Chase, author and vice president, Cunningham and Walsh

node.title: American genius for self-examination
node.description: The American Genius for Self-Examination. Alan Pryce-Jones of New York Herald Tribune and Russell Lynes of Harper's.
